aboutPage.title: About Natural Fluency
aboutPage.p1: We are linguists, actors, and executives. We built Natural Fluency because we saw brilliant professionals shrinking in English-speaking rooms.
aboutPage.p2: The traditional ESL industry treats language like math: memorize the rules, and you'll get the answer. But speaking isn't math. It's music. It's rhythm, timing, and confidence.
aboutPage.p3: Our methodology is based on "Interactive Empathy"—the science of how human connection overrides performance anxiety. We don't just teach you words; we teach you how to hold space.

nav.interfaceOnly: Interface only. Learning content remains in English.

problems.label: The Problem
problems.headline: Why apps can't teach you this.
problems.p1: Most language apps teach you vocabulary (what to say). But in a real meeting, you don't struggle because you lack words.
problems.p3: When the stakes go up, your brain reverts to safety: translating from your native language. This delay is what kills your confidence, not your grammar.

speakingMoments.headline: Moments where speaking English feels hardest
speakingMoments.subtext: These are not grammar problems. They’re timing problems.

modal.whyHardDesc: You're trying to prepare everything before speaking.

items.title: Explaining a delay
items.description: When you know what happened but struggle to start explaining.
items.example: “Can you explain why this was delayed?”
items.reframe: Starting matters more than perfect explanation.

items.title: Being asked unexpectedly
items.description: When you understand the question but your mind goes blank.
items.example: “What do you think about this idea?”
items.reframe: You don’t need an answer — you need an entry.

items.title: Disagreeing politely
items.description: When you want to disagree but fear sounding rude.
items.example: “I’m not sure I agree with that.”
items.reframe: Tone comes from pacing, not vocabulary.

items.title: Clarifying a misunderstanding
items.description: When something goes wrong and you need to explain yourself.

items.title: Joining a conversation late
items.description: When the discussion is already moving fast.

items.title: Losing your sentence halfway
items.description: When you start speaking and forget what you wanted to say.
items.example: “What I was trying to say is…”
